nodes.description: Richard Reid attempted to board American Airlines Flight 63 from Paris to Miami on December 22, 2001, but was initially denied entry at Charles de Gaulle Airport due to incomplete answers
nodes.support_text: Sources in France said that Reid attempted Friday to board an American Airlines Paris-to-Miami flight, but authorities at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris would not let him aboard when he did not answer all their questions.

nodes.description: Reid was allowed to re-board Flight 63 after French authorities verified his British passport and reissued his ticket
nodes.support_text: He was turned over to French National Police, who concluded his British passport was genuine and allowed American Airlines to reissue the man's ticket for Flight 63 the next day, sources said.

nodes.description: During the flight, flight attendant Hermis Moutardier detected a burnt match smell and confronted Reid who lit a match in his mouth
nodes.support_text: A flight attendant smelled what she thought was a burnt match at about 11 a.m., 90 minutes into the flight. A passenger directed the flight attendant, Hermis Moutardier, to Reid, who was seated in row 29 in the coach section.

nodes.description: Reid attempted to ignite his shoes' inner tongue with a second match while flight attendants and passengers struggled to subdue him
nodes.support_text: Reid lit a match in his mouth, according to a criminal complaint the FBI filed. Moutardier then saw him light another match, and he appeared to be trying to set fire to the inner tongue of his sneaker.

nodes.description: Reid bit flight attendant Cristina Jones during the struggle and was eventually subdued by passengers using sedatives
nodes.support_text: When a second flight attendant, Cristina Jones, joined the fracas, Reid bit her on the thumb, the affidavit said.

nodes.description: Flight 63 was diverted to Boston Logan International Airport and landed safely at 12:50 PM EST
nodes.support_text: The plane was diverted to Boston's Logan International Airport, where it landed safely.

nodes.description: U.S. Magistrate Judith Dein approved extended custody for Reid due to flight risk and dangerousness during the January 1, 2002 hearing
nodes.support_text: At Monday's brief hearing, Reid was read his rights but did not enter a plea because he does not have an attorney yet. U.S. Magistrate Judith Dein approved a request by U.S. attorneys for Reid to remain in custody until the pending trial because of the dangerousness of the situation and his risk of flight.

nodes.description: FBI analysis confirmed Reid's shoes contained two functional IEDs with approximately 10 ounces of explosive material
nodes.support_text: The FBI's preliminary analysis of Reid's shoes showed they contained 'two functional improvised explosive devices,' federal authorities said Sunday.

nodes.description: The FAA mandated random shoe inspections for all flights following the incident
nodes.support_text: As a result of Saturday's events, the Federal Aviation Administration issued a security directive Sunday ordering airlines to add random shoe inspections to the random baggage checks already carried out.

nodes.description: Reid's identity confusion emerged as French authorities identified him as Abdel Raheem while U.S. officials linked him to Tariq Raja
nodes.support_text: Though the man's passport identified him as Richard Colvin Reid, a French Border Police spokesman said the FBI identified him as Tariq Raja, born August 12, 1973, in Sri Lanka.

nodes.description: British and French authorities confirmed Reid's British citizenship despite conflicting passport information
nodes.support_text: New Scotland Yard and French authorities said he is a British citizen.

edges.support_text: He was turned over to French National Police, who concluded his British passport was genuine and allowed American Airlines to reissue the man's ticket for Flight 63 the next day, sources said.
A flight attendant smelled what she thought was a burnt match at about 11 a.m., 90 minutes into the flight.
Reid lit a match in his mouth, according to a criminal complaint the FBI filed.
When a second flight attendant, Cristina Jones, joined the fracas, Reid bit her on the thumb, the affidavit said.
The plane was diverted to Boston's Logan International Airport, where it landed safely.
At Monday's brief hearing, Reid was read his rights but did not enter a plea because he does not have an attorney yet.
The FBI's preliminary analysis of Reid's shoes showed they contained 'two functional improvised explosive devices,' federal authorities said Sunday.
As a result of Saturday's events, the Federal Aviation Administration issued a security directive Sunday ordering airlines to add random shoe inspections...
Though the man's passport identified him as Richard Colvin Reid, a French Border Police spokesman said the FBI identified him as Tariq Raja...
New Scotland Yard and French authorities said he is a British citizen.
航班安全检查导致行李复查
